NBA Early-Career Competition Analysis

Executive Summary

Objective

This project examines how rookie- and sophomore-year positional competition influences NBA lottery picks’ scoring trajectories across their first five seasons. Early-career positional competition measures how crowded a player’s role is on their team.

Methods

  • Data collection: Web-scraped player career stats from Basketball Reference with Python (requests, BeautifulSoup), cleaned with pandas and R (dplyr).
  • Modeling: Linear mixed-effects models (lmer) with natural splines to capture nonlinear growth, including random intercepts/slopes for players.
  • Validation: Bootstrapped confidence intervals, ran key model diagnostic tests.
  • Visualization: Insightful trajectory and interaction plots built in ggplot2, with interactive versions via plotly.

Key Visualization

Key Takeaways

  • Sophomore-year competition matters: On average, players facing more competition in their second year start strong but flatten or decline after Year 3.

  • Rookie-year competition has little impact on early-career scoring growth, though it slightly raises baseline scoring.

  • Overall: Early-career competition is associated with accelerated short-term growth but may reduce long-term development.

Why It Matters

The methods used here apply well beyond sports.

  • Business & Marketing: modeling customer lifetime value under varying market conditions

  • Healthcare: understanding how patient outcomes evolve under different treatment exposures.

  • Education: analyzing how student performance changes when facing different classroom environments.
